docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate moved today toward a showdown on legislation to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly, as Democrats raced to round up Republican votes for a proposal that directs assistance mainly to people with low incomes or high drug costs. A Senate vote is scheduled on Wednesday, and Democrats said that as of this evening they did not have the 60 votes they would need under Senate budget rules. If the proposal fails, that could mean the demise of Medicare drug benefits for this year, though members of both parties said the Senate could pass the underlying bill, to speed the approval and marketing of low-cost generic drugs.

headline.main: Big Senate Vote on Medicare Drug Benefits Is Set for Today

docs.abstract: Senate moves toward showdown on prescription drug benefits for the elderly, as Democrats race to round up Republican votes for direct aid to people with low incomes or high drug costs; Democrat Bob Graham and Republican Gordon H Smith sponsor compromise (M)
docs.snippet: The Senate moved today toward a showdown on legislation to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly, as Democrats raced to round up Republican votes for a proposal that directs assistance mainly to people with low incomes or high drug costs....

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc., the Cigna Corporation, Humana Inc. and other health insurers lost a bid to bar plaintiffs' lawyers from obtaining internal records in cases that accuse the companies of skimping on patient care. Judge Federico Moreno of United States District Court in Miami issued a one-page ruling today instructing the insurers that, beginning Sept. 30, they must provide documents requested by lawyers for the plaintiffs, according to a court order.

headline.main: Health Insurers Lose Bid on Case Records

docs.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said yesterday that Blue Cross of California and its parent company, WellPoint Health Networks, had agreed to pay $9.25 million to resolve claims that the company had defrauded Medicare. Blue Cross California, which was under contract with the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services to process Medicare claims in California until December 2000, was accused of falsifying data about its performance of cost report audits for Medicare, the Justice Department said. Blue Cross of California was responsible for auditing cost reports and reimbursement requests submitted by Medicare service providers.

headline.main: WELLPOINT PAYS $9.25 MILLION IN MEDICARE FRAUD CASE

docs.abstract: Justice Department says Blue Cross of California and parent WellPoint Health Networks will pay $9.25 million to resolve claims that company defrauded Medicare; says Blue Cross falsified data about its auditing for Medicare of cost reports submitted by Medicare service providers (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett is buying on the cheap again. A unit of Mr. Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway agreed yesterday to buy a natural gas pipeline that had belonged to Enron and fell into the hands of Dynegy during their unsuccessful merger last fall.

headline.main: Berkshire to Buy a Gas Pipeline From Dynegy

docs.abstract: MidAmerican Energy Holdings, unit of Warren E Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway, will buy Northern Natural Gas Co, natural gas pipeline owner, for $928 million from Dynegy; Dynegy acquired pipeline for $1.5 billion in November as part of failed plan to merge with Enron; MidAmerican has been aggressively seeking undervalued assets owned by troubled energy companies (M)
docs.snippet: Warren E. Buffett is buying on the cheap again.    A unit of Mr. Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway agreed yesterday to buy a natural gas pipeline that had belonged to Enron and fell into the hands of Dynegy during their unsuccessful merger last fall.

docs.lead_paragraph: High technology, with Microsoft at the helm, has put Seattle on the map. Still, lumber and agriculture formed the city's industrial backbone, and the old economy continues to play an important role in the Puget Sound area. The retailers Nordstrom and Costco are here, as are the insurance giant Safeco (which has acquired naming rights to the home of the Seattle Mariners, Safeco Field) and, of course, Starbucks and its ubiquitous coffee houses. The wobbly American economy has not spared Seattle. The jobless rate, which hovered around 3.3 percent in the late 1990's, has doubled since then, and the once robust housing market has weakened. Boeing's decision to move its world headquarters to Chicago last year cost the area 13,800 jobs, to say nothing of a measure of Seattle's pride. On the other hand, Amazon recently reported quarterly results that were slightly better than expected.

headline.main: ON THE GROUND: In Seattle; Old Economy Still Vital In High-Technology City

docs.abstract: Lynn Elsey article on places for business travelers to stay, eat and visit in Seattle; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Like millions of Americans, Caroline Polk, a freelance editor in Washington, was left deeply unnerved by the Sept. 11 attacks. She could not sleep and felt tense and nervous all the time. Unable to calm herself, she decided to go for counseling, paying out of her own pocket. After four months, her anxiety had subsided, and she quit.

headline.main: After Treatment for Mental Illness, Fight for Insurance Often Follows

docs.abstract: Article on reluctance of health insurance providers to offer individual coverage, at least at low-cost 'preferred' rates, to people with history of mental conditions; notes some 16 million Americans, those who are self-employed or have lost jobs and group benefits, rely on individual plans; insurers say reluctance to cover those with mental illness is justified; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission called on Congress tonight to revise the nation's patent laws to prevent brand-name drug companies from unduly delaying the sale of low-cost generic drugs. In a report to be issued on Tuesday, the commission says several provisions of a landmark 1984 law ''have the potential for abuse'' and may have been exploited by brand-name drug companies to prevent the marketing of generic drugs.

headline.main: Patent Law Change Urged To Speed Generic Drugs

docs.abstract: Federal Trade Commission calls on Congress to revise 1984 patent law to prevent brand-name drug companies from unduly delaying sale of low-cost generic drugs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: TAB Products, a document-storage and tracking company, agreed today to be bought by HS Morgan Limited Partnership for about $34 million. HS Morgan will pay $5.85 a share in cash, a 27 percent premium over Friday's closing price. The purchase is expected to close in the fourth quarter, TAB said in a statement.
docs.abstract: HS Morgan Limited Partnership will buy TAB Products, document-storage and tracking company, for about $34 million in cash (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Westchester County budget director, Kathleen M. Carrano, recently laid out some of the options for county officials trying to close a $102-million budget gap in the coming year. Lay off 402 employees and cut 58 vacancies.

headline.main: A Grim Choice In Westchester: Harsh Cutbacks Or Higher Taxes

docs.abstract: Westchester County Budget Dir Kathleen M Carrano recently laid out some of options for county officials trying to close $102-million budget gap in coming year; cutbacks and others account for only $65 million in county expenses, leaving another $37 million to go; County Executive Andrew J Spano warned last week that county might be forced to cut programs and services drastically, or raise property levy by 29 percent or higher; has called for 1 percent increase in sales tax that would collect extra $100 million per year, of which $75 million would pay for increased costs for Medicaid and other state-mandated progams; graph (M)
docs.snippet: The Westchester County budget director, Kathleen M. Carrano, recently laid out some of the options for county officials trying to close a $102-million budget gap in the coming year.     Lay off 402 employees and cut 58 vacancies.

docs.lead_paragraph: The political debate over how to add a prescription drug benefit to Medicare has dragged on now for more than four years. Prescription drugs have become an integral part of health care delivery, but unlike insurance for most working families, the Medicare program for older and disabled people provides almost no drug coverage. Politicians from both parties know they have to do something, but the hurdles are big: money and control. The debate in the Senate is still ongoing. But large differences along party lines remain, and the Republican House plan that was passed on a party line vote in June makes hopes for compromise remote given the desires of consumers for broad coverage and of drug companies for minimal government controls.

headline.main: Finding a Formula for Medicare Drug Benefits

docs.abstract: Marilyn Moon Op-Ed article examines obstacles thwarting Senate passage of bill to provide prescription drug benefits for Medicare recipients; says main problems are money and control, noting large differences between Republicans and Democrats and fact that sums needed are enormous; says lawmakers and rest of Americans must ultimately decide whether they trust government to deliver new drug benefit effectively; says need for drug coverage is too great to let issue remain unresolved (M)
